raw_text:
Online commons to spark debate
 
 Online communities set up by the UK government could encourage public debate and build trust, says the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR).
 
 Existing services such as eBay could provide a good blueprint for such services, says the think-tank. Although the net is becoming part of local and central government, its potential has not yet been fully exploited to create an online "commons" for public debate. In its report, Is Online Community A Policy Tool?, the IPPR also asks if ID cards could help create safer online communities. Adopting an eBay-type model would let communities create their own markets for skills and services and help foster a sense of local identity and connection. "What we are proposing is a civic commons," Will Davies, senior research fellow at the IPPR told the BBC News website. "A single publicly funded and run online community in which citizens can have a single place to go where you can go to engage in diversity and in a way that might have a policy implication - like a pre-legislation discussion."
 
 The idea of a "civic commons" was originally proposed by Stephen Coleman, professor of e-democracy at the Oxford Internet Institute. The IPPR report points to informal, small scale examples of such commons that already exist. It mentions good-practice public initiatives like the BBC's iCan project which connects people locally and nationally who want to take action around important issues.
 
 But he adds, government could play a bigger role in setting up systems of trust for online communities too. Proposals for ID cards, for instance, could also be widened to see if they could be used online. They could provide the basis for a secure authentication system which could have value for peer-to-peer interaction online. "At the moment they have been presented as a way for government to keep tabs on people and ensuring access to public services," said Mr Davies. "But what has not been explored is how authentication technology may potentially play a role in decentralised online communities." The key idea to take from systems such as eBay and other online communities is letting members rate each other's reputation by how they treat other members. Using a similar mechanism, trust and cooperation between members of virtual and physical communities could be built. This could mean a civic commons would work within a non-market system which lets people who may disagree with one another interact within publicly-recognised rules.
 
 E-government initiatives over the last decade have very much been about putting basic information and service guides online as well as letting people interact with government via the web. Many online communities, such as chatrooms, mailing lists, community portals, message boards and weblogs often form around common interests or issues.
 
 With 53% of UK households now with access to the net, the government, suggests Mr Davies, could act as an intermediary or "middleman" to set up public online places of debate and exchange to encourage more "cosmopolitan politics" and public trust in policy. "Government already plays a critical role in helping citizens trade with each other online. "But it should also play a role in helping citizens connect to one another in civic, non-market interactions," said Mr Davies. There is a role for public bodies like the BBC, libraries, and government to bring people back into public debate again instead of millions of "cliques" talking to each other, he added. The paper is part of the IPPR's Digital Society initiative which is producing a number of conferences and research papers leading up to the publication of A Manifesto For A Digital Britain.
llama3.2:1b: Online communities could be established by the UK government to encourage public debate and build trust, using existing services such as eBay as a model.
The idea of a "civic commons" was first proposed by Stephen Coleman, which involves creating an online platform where citizens can engage in diversity and have policy implications.
llama3.2:3b: The UK government could establish online communities to encourage public debate and build trust, building on existing services like eBay.

This "civic commons" would provide a platform for citizens to engage in diversity and discussion, potentially using ID card technology to create secure authentication systems for peer-to-peer interaction.
The idea is to foster local identity and connection, promoting "cosmopolitan politics" and public trust in policy.
gemma2:2b: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) believes that online communities could foster public debate and build trust, similar to eBay.
They suggest government should create an "online commons" for open discussion and engagement, allowing citizens to connect on diverse issues.
The report proposes using ID card technology for secure authentication in these communities, building trust based on reputation ratings like those found on market platforms.
The IPPR advocates for a non-market system that fosters respectful interaction between people with differing viewpoints, facilitating "cosmopolitan politics."
They argue that government should act as an intermediary to facilitate public online dialogue and engagement by connecting citizens through digital spaces beyond basic information services.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Online communities could help spark public debate by providing platforms for citizens to engage in diversity, share experiences, and foster policy discussions.
eBay and other existing services could serve as prototypes for similar online "commons."
Government could also play a role by implementing ID cards that could be used within online spaces.
A civic commons is proposed where people can register their reputation and interact through publicly-recognized rules.
E-government initiatives have already played a role in bringing citizens together online, but there's an opportunity for the government to bring back public debate into the digital age.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK government could encourage public debate through online commons set up by its community services, building on eBay's model for "civic commons" that uses ratings to foster trust and cooperation between members.
The report suggests government roles in setting up systems for authentication technology like ID cards to ensure safe online communities.
qwen2.5:3b: Online communities set by UK government could foster public debate and trust, according to IPPR.
Existing platforms like eBay provide a blueprint for creating an online "commons" for public engagement.
The report suggests ID cards could help build safer online communities through secure authentication systems.
The concept of a civic commons involves citizens engaging in discussions on shared issues without market interactions.
IPPR proposes government as a middleman to set up public spaces for debate, aiming to increase public trust and promote more inclusive political discourse in the digital age.
opencoder:1.5b:
Online commons to spark debate

Government has already played a crucial role in connecting people over the internet, facilitating trades and fostering public trust in policy.
Yet, as with all online communities, citizens should be able to connect and engage in diverse and relevant means of public discourse.
This is where a civic commons might come into play.
It could provide a space for citizens to share knowledge, gather ideas, and build relationships.
The aim is not merely to promote public debate but also to foster a sense of local identity and connection.

A single publicly funded and run online community where citizens can have a place to go where they can engage in diversity and in a way that might have a policy implication - like pre-legislation discussions.
Through good practices, it could offer a platform for citizen interaction not only within the government but also across various public bodies and sectors.
smollm:1.7b: The text summary above aims to capture the essence of the original text while omitting unnecessary details and focusing on the main ideas, key points, and supporting arguments.
The summary should preserve the tone, style, and language used in the original text.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK government's efforts to create online commons for public debate are highlighted in the IPPR report.
These services aim to encourage diversity and engagement by allowing citizens to engage in diverse topics within a single platform.
Examples like eBay can guide such models, emphasizing mechanisms like reputation ratings and secure authentication.
The report suggests that these platforms should function as intermediaries between citizens, promoting civic interactions beyond traditional online spaces.
It also notes the role of public bodies like the BBC in reintegrating people into broader debate.
tinyllama:1.1b: The online common "commons" proposed by the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) could encourage public debate, foster a sense of local identity and connection through creating safe online communities, while setting up public online places of debate and encouraging more "cosmopolitan politics".
This model is proposed to be part of an eBay-type model that creates marketplaces for skills and services.
The paper highlights the benefits and potential applications of such platforms, especially in areas like education or healthcare.

However, the proposal also raises questions about how government could set up public online places of debate and promote trust in policy while playing a role in encouraging citizen-to-citizen interactions.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, online communities can play a vital role in promoting public debate and encouraging greater trust among citizens by providing a blueprint for creating an online "commons" for public debate.
The idea was proposed by Stephen Coleman at the Oxford Internet Institute and has been suggested that ID cards could help set up such systems.
However, government could also play a bigger role in setting up secure authentication systems for online communities to ensure access to public services.
phi:2.7b: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) suggests that government-set up online communities could encourage public debate and build trust, using existing services like eBay as a blueprint.
An online "civic commons" where citizens can interact with each other in a secure authentication system is proposed.
This would help build trust between members of virtual and physical communities and allow people who may disagree to interact within publicly-recognised rules.
orca-mini:3b: Online commons could spark debate and build trust, says report.
ID cards could help create safer online communities, suggests think-tank.
Civic commons proposed as a single publicly funded and run online community where citizens can interact around important issues.
E-government initiatives could play a role in setting up systems of trust for online communities.
hermes3:3b: Online commons for UK public debate and trust, based on eBay-like model; could use ID cards for secure authentication systems.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) suggests that online communities established by the UK government could promote public debate and build trust, drawing parallels with eBay's model.
These online "commons" could create markets for skills and services within communities while fostering a sense of local identity and connection.
The idea of a civic commons was originally proposed by Stephen Coleman, professor of e-democracy at the Oxford Internet Institute.

IPPR believes that government could play a larger role in establishing systems of trust for online communities and even considers wider adoption of ID cards to create a secure authentication system for decentralized online interactions.

Building on good-practice public initiatives like the BBC's iCan project, the report argues that the government can serve as an intermediary or "middleman" to establish public spaces for debate, encouraging more "cosmopolitan politics" and building trust in policy.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) suggests that UK government-backed online communities could foster public debate and trust, using models like eBay as a blueprint.
Their report, *Is Online Community A Policy Tool?
*, explores the potential of a publicly funded "civic commons" where citizens can engage in discussions with policy implications.
The idea, originally proposed by Professor Stephen Coleman, highlights existing small-scale examples like the BBC's iCan project.
The report also suggests that ID cards could be used for secure authentication in online communities, enhancing trust and cooperation.
By adopting reputation-rating mechanisms similar to eBay, a civic commons could facilitate non-market interactions under publicly recognized rules.

While past e-government initiatives have focused on providing information and services, the government could now act as an intermediary to create public spaces for debate, fostering broader political engagement.
The IPPR's Digital Society initiative continues to explore these ideas, culminating in *A Manifesto For A Digital Britain*.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) proposes online communities established by the UK government as a means for public debate and trust-building.
Examples like eBay could serve as models.

The IPPR suggests adopting an eBay- or ID card-type model to create single, publicly funded and run online communities where citizens can engage in diverse discussions that may have policy implications.
The idea is to let members rate each other's reputation by how they treat other members within these communities.
E-government initiatives have focused on putting basic information and services online, as well as facilitating interaction with the government via the web.
With 25% of UK households with internet access, there is potential for using digital platforms to encourage cosmopolitan politics and public trust in policy.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) proposes an online "civic commons" as a policy tool for fostering public debate, trust, and policy implications in the UK.
This concept is inspired by existing online services like eBay, which allow communities to create markets for skills and services, promoting local identity and connection.

The IPPR suggests that government can play a larger role in establishing systems of trust for these online communities, potentially through the use of ID cards as a secure authentication mechanism for peer-to-peer interactions.
This would enable members to rate each other's reputations based on their behavior within the community.
By leveraging informal examples and e-government initiatives, the government could act as an intermediary, setting up public online spaces for debate and connection among citizens.
The goal is to encourage "cosmopolitan politics" and rebuild public trust in policy, moving away from fragmented online cliques.
This proposal is part of the IPPR's Digital Society initiative, aiming to produce a Manifesto For A Digital Britain.
